text:
-Looking at ground zero today,
busy with commuters and

tourists, it's hard to imagine
that five years ago, this

place was smothered by a vortex
of dust and ash so

thick it blacked out
the sun and turned
the day into a nightmare.

Thousands of people were
engulfed by the dust that day.

And in the weeks and months
afterwards, when the dust lay

over everything, many thousands
more continued to
breathe it in.

Some experts suspected right
from the beginning that the

dust presented a serious
health hazard.
But no one knew for sure.

Then, people started
getting sick.

The first indication that
something was wrong came out

of the New York City
Fire Department.

Working directly on the huge
pile, often without proper

respiratory equipment, many
of the 12,000 firefighters

started coming down with nasal
and sinus irritations.
The culprit?

The dust, especially the
large particles.

Scientific analysis of the
dust showed it to be as
caustic as drain cleaner.

But later studies showed
that it wasn't just the

firefighters who were hurt by
the dust. In 2004, the Mount

Sinai Center for Occupational
and Environmental Medicine

published a medical report,
showing that more than half of

the steel workers, and other
people who worked in the

massive recovery and cleanup
operations, complained of

significant respiratory problems
that had developed
after 9/11.

The federal government provided
money for screening
the workers.

But they were left mostly on
their own when it came to

getting treatment for the
asthmas, sinusitis, and

gastrointestinal problems
they had developed.
-Good morning.

I'm Congresswoman Carolyn
Maloney, and I represent parts
of Manhattan and Queens.

All of us know that many,
many people lost
their lives on 9/11.

Yet many, many more
lost their health.

We wish we were not
here today.

We wish the government
had responded to the
needs of the people.

They would rather have their
treatment than to be called by

all the elected officials
heroes and heroines.

-Then, in the first weeks of
2006 came the death of a

34-year-old New York City
detective, James Zadroga, who

had clocked hundreds of
hours at ground zero.

The coroner's report officially
linked his death,

and the terrible scarring on his
lungs that had led to his

death, to his work on the
pile at ground zero.

It was the first, and so far
the only, official link

between the dust and the
death of a responder.

Since Detective Zadroga's death,
the federal government

has openly acknowledged that the
dust is causing a variety
of ailments.

In February, Dr. John Howard was
named national coordinator
for 9/11 health problems.

-We've never had a city,
a United States city,
attacked like this.

We've never produced this
kind of a dust cloud.

So I think we're working our
way through that issue.

So I think the reason it's
taking so long is because

we're all coming to this
realization which I don't

think any of us expected, that
five years later, we would be

seeing people with
health effects.

-The federal government finally
allocated money, more

than $50 million, to provide
treatment for some of the ill
responders.

But Dr. Howard concedes that
it won't go very far,

especially if, as some doctors
fear, there may be a sharp

increase in cancers and
leukemias linked to the dust.

-It is the most significant
event in our recent memory.

And it's becoming the most
significant medical event

also, in terms of how do you
take care of people who

responded and who were affected
by this disaster.

And it's involving
a lot of folks in
terms of that thinking.

How do we get through
this period of time?

And how do we provide the best
medical information and

services to affected
populations?

-So far, there have been delays,
timid responses, and

such a lack of scientific rigor
about understanding the

problem that nobody knows how
far the dust traveled or how

many offices and apartments
might have been contaminated.

All that has shattered the sense
of trust in government.

And that, Dr. Howard
says, has serious
implications for the future.

What if there is another
attack, another
environmental disaster?

Will people be willing to listen
to government officials

if there is a need
to evacuate?

And will they trust officials
if they are told that it is
safe to come back?

At ground zero, this is Anthony
DePalma for the New
York Times.
